newsitem.title: VENEZUELA: Venezuela to use oil windfall to pay off debt.
newsitem.headline: Venezuela to use oil windfall to pay off debt.

text.p: Venezuelan ministers cautiously welcomed windfall oil revenues produced by renewed tension in the Middle East and insisted that the extra cash would go to pay off foreign debt.

"For every extra dollar in the oil price (per barrel), 100 billion bolivars ($210 million) goes to the Treasury and will be used to pay this heavy burden of debt," Energy and Mines Minister Erwin Arrieta told reporters.
The Venezuelan government recently established a special account to place revenues from oil exceeding $14.70 per barrel. The account is to be used to pay off outstanding debt.
Arrieta announced that Venezuela's basket of crude and products had risen to $20.12 per barrel on Wednesday, up from $19.05 on Friday. The average for the year so far is $17.19 per barrel, he said.
Planning Minister Teodoro Petkoff, meanwhile, warned that "downpour of dollars" caused by rising oil prices could tempt the government to forget its austere economic reform program.
"We are being careful to not forget the necessity of this adjustment," Petkoff said in an interview with Radio Caracas.
Venezuela launched an economic reform program in April aimed at reducing the fiscal deficit and cutting inflation.
